dw-article.title: Build a DevOps dashboard
dw-article.subtitle: Display real-time information for cross-functional teams

author.bio: Paul Duvall is the CTO of Stelligent. A featured speaker at many leading software conferences, he has worked in virtually every role on software projects: developer, project manager, architect, and tester. He is the principal author of Continuous Integration: Improving Software Quality and Reducing Risk (Addison-Wesley, 2007) and a 2008 Jolt Award Winner. He is also the author of Startup@Cloud and DevOps in the Cloud LiveLessons (Pearson Education, June 2012). He's contributed to several other books as well. Paul authored the 20-article Automation for the people series on developerWorks. He is passionate about getting high-quality software to users quicker and more often through continuous delivery and the cloud. Read his blog at Stelligent.com.

dw-article.abstract: What if you could get instant feedback on the health of your software system with every change applied -- not only to the software application, but also to the database, infrastructure, and configuration? In this final Agile DevOps installment, DevOps expert Paul Duvall helps you set up a DevOps dashboard by using the open source CanaryBoard tool. The dashboard reveals the state of the entire software system under development -- from check-in to production -- at a glance.
dw-article.abstract-extended: What if you could get instant feedback on the health of your software system with every change applied not only to the software application, but also to the database, infrastructure, and configuration? In this final Agile DevOps installment, DevOps expert Paul Duvall helps you set up a DevOps dashboard by using the open source CanaryBoard tool. The dashboard reveals the state of the entire software system under development from check-in to production at a glance.

sidebar.heading: About this series
sidebar.p: Developers can learn a lot from operations, and operations can learn a lot from developers. This series of articles is dedicated to exploring the practical uses of applying an operations mindset to development, and vice versa and of considering software products as holistic entities that can be delivered with more agility and frequency than ever before.

docbody.p: So far in this series, you've learned:

ul.li: How DevOps and Continuous Delivery are flattening the release process
How you can describe your infrastructure in code by using tools like Chef or Puppet
How you can write tests for your infrastructure and deployments
How to ensure that your infrastructure is resilient with tools like the Chaos Monkey
How to create a Continuous Delivery platform
How to version all software system assets

docbody.p: And because the organizational aspects of DevOps are just as important as the technical ones, I've also prescribed ways to break down traditional development and operations silos to enhance teamwork and communication.

When your whole software system is described in code and committed to a version-control repository, changes occur frequently, creating a crucial need for accurate real-time feedback for everyone on your team or in your organization. In this last article in the Agile DevOps series, you'll learn how you can tie all of this feedback together and present it in an easy-to-digest form through a DevOps dashboard. All cross-functional team members in your organization can use the dashboard to learn the status of the system under development and in production. They can then make informed decisions based on reality rather than on the perceptions of the more vocal team members.
docbody.heading: Introducing CanaryBoard
docbody.p: CanaryBoard is an open source tool that's modeled on the Stashboard open source tool (which is based on tools from large cloud providers). CanaryBoard is intended to provide a log of the status of applications or services by project, but you can customize it to show whatever you choose. And you can run CanaryBoard by using purely open source platforms.

Figure 1 shows a dashboard that I customized to show the status of some DevOps indicators (Environment, Build, Test, and Deploy) for a project. By running scripts when every code check-in occurs, I can update the dashboard automatically to provide a real-time status for each indicator.

figure.heading: Figure 1. DevOps dashboard status using CanaryBoard

img.alt: Screen capture of a dashboard using the open-source CanaryBoard framework. The dashboard shows four DevOps indicators: Environment, Build, Test. and Deploy. The left-most column provides the most current state of these DevOps indicators.

docbody.p: You can customize your CanaryBoard dashboard to show anything that's important for your team or organization. You can also create multiple dashboards to reflect various levels within your organization. Many other dashboard platforms are available that integrate with other tools that you might already be using; some dashboard platforms are free and open source, and others require monthly fees. As a developer, I like to have full control not only of customization, but also of the platforms that the software can run on. That's why my company created CanaryBoard.
docbody.heading: Setting up the DevOps dashboard

sidebar.heading: Choices, choices
sidebar.p: You can run CanaryBoard on virtually any OS, and you can use almost any programming language to modify the data pushed to the service through its REST API. This article uses:

ul.li: Ruby to access CanaryBoard's RESTful API
The same Linux instance to run the CanaryBoard scripts

sidebar.p: Although the examples are specific to this collection of tools, you can slightly alter the instructions to fit the needs of your own infrastructure provider, OS, packaging system, and programming language.

docbody.p: To get the CanaryBoard tool up and running on a Linux instance, launch and access a compute instance, install the required packages, download and configure files, and run CanaryBoard.
docbody.heading: Step 1: Download and launch the server
docbody.p: Download Ubuntu 12.04 LTS server (see Resources for a link to the download page). Then launch your Ubuntu instance.
docbody.heading: Step 2: Install packages
docbody.p: ssh into the server and run the commands described in the Installing Railsâ€¦ section of the CanaryBoard readme located at https://github.com/stelligent/canaryboard/. In running these commands, you will install all necessary packages including the Ruby Version Manager (RVM), Ruby, Git and Rails. (If you're using a packaging system other than apt-get such as yum or rpm modify the commands accordingly.)
Now that you've installed all of the packages, you're ready to install, configure, and run CanaryBoard.
docbody.heading: Step 3: Install, configure, and run CanaryBoard
docbody.p: CanaryBoard is a Rails application and RESTful API that was developed by Stelligent and that's hosted on GitHub. You need to follow a few simple steps to get the application up and running and they are described within the Installing CanaryBoard section of the CanaryBoard readme located at https://github.com/stelligent/canaryboard/. These steps include getting the latest copy from the Git repository, installing any Ruby gems required by CanaryBoard, setting up and seeding the database, running automated tests and starting the Rails server.
Launch the website for your CanaryBoard application by typing http://localhost:3000 in your browser. (If necessary, change localhost to your server location.) Be sure that port 3000 is available.
You should see an empty status board like the one in Figure 2:

figure.heading: Figure 2. Blank dashboard ready to be configured

img.alt: Screen capture of an empty dashboard created with the CanaryBoard framework

docbody.p: Click the Log in link to display a login screen similar to Figure 3:

img.alt: Login screen for the CanaryBoard Rails application.

docbody.p: Enter the default username (admin) and default password (admin). After logging in, click the Profile link, then click Edit to change your password to something other than the default.

To run this article's example code, you need to get the API Key that's set as part of the data seeding. Go back to your profile (http://localhost:3000/profile) and copy the API Key value. Figure 4 shows an example of the profile screen with an API Key:

figure.heading: Figure 4. User profile used to get API Key

img.alt: Screen capture of the CanaryBoard user profile page that displays the API key

docbody.heading: Programmatically updating the DevOps dashboard
docbody.p: You'll use two Ruby scripts to create the dashboard's indicators through the CanaryBoard REST API. They will be called set-indicators.rb and update-indicators.rb.

Begin at the Linux server command prompt and create a new Ruby file called set-indicators.rb. Paste the customized contents from the example in the set-indicators.rb available in the Using CanaryBoard section of the readme located at https://github.com/stelligent/canaryboard. If you're not running your server on localhost, change localhost to your server's location as part of the API_URL variable. Change the API_KEY value from changeme to the value that you got from the CanaryBoard profile page. You will run this script later.

sidebar.heading: Versatile scripts
sidebar.p: Keep in mind that with modifications you can use this article's scripts on virtually any other platform that can run Ruby on Rails.

docbody.p: Now, from the Linux server's command line, create a new Ruby file called update-indicators.rb. Paste the customized contents of the code listing from the Using CanaryBoard section of the CanaryBoard readme into the update-indicators.rb file that you just created. If you're not running your server on localhost, change localhost to your server's location as part of the API_URL variable. Change the API_KEY value from changeme to the value that you got from the CanaryBoard profile page.
The update-indicators.rb script uses Ruby to update the dashboard's indicators through the CanaryBoard REST API.
Use these commands (which assume that your set-indicators.rb and update-indicator.rb files are in the home directory on your instance) to run the Ruby programs:

Go to https://localhost:3000/ (or equivalent) to see the results of the services and events that you created. When the code in update-indicators.rb runs, it updates all of the events for the services that are listed in the script. By clicking on any indicator in the dashboard, you can see a history of these events. If you want this script to run with every code check-in, you can call it from your Continuous Integration server or run it through cron or another scheduling system. Figure 5 shows example results for the Deploy service:

figure.heading: Figure 5. Event log for the Deploy service indicator

img.alt: Screen capture of a CanaryBoard page that shows a history of the events logged for the Deploy indicator. Each row contains a date- and time-stamped description of a event that's related to deployment.

docbody.p: set-indicators.rb and update-indicators.rb are hard-coded for specific services, but you can make all of the code dynamic.
docbody.heading: In conclusion

sidebar.heading: Get involved
sidebar.p: The developerWorks Agile transformation community provides news, discussions, and training to help you and your organization build a foundation on agile development principles.

docbody.p: In this article, the last in the Agile DevOps series, you learned how to use the open source CanaryBoard tool to provide continuous feedback to all team members across development and operations. Many system- and application-monitoring tools provide a plethora of rich information that you can incorporate into DevOps dashboards to help engineers and others make more-informed decisions.

It's been a tremendous adventure sharing my experiences with you over the past several months. My goal with this series has been to show how and why to learn the best approaches and practices from teams and cultures that traditionally are completely different: development and operations. I encourage you to view software as holistic, integrated systems not as something that gets "thrown over the wall" to another team in your organization.
